newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK banks not ready for "millennium bug" - survey.
newsitem.headline: HK banks not ready for "millennium bug" - survey.

text.p: Almost half of Hong Kong's banks have not planned for the the millennium bug -- the expected mass malfunction of computers in 2000 -- the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) said on Tuesday.
HKMA deputy chief executive David Carse told a seminar that 46 percent of financial institutions surveyed by the HKMA had no plans for dealing with the problem, Hong Kong government radio reported.
Carse said the HKMA might initially produce general guidelines for financial institutions.
"We're dealing with a huge variety of systems here and I don't think we can impose one common standard which can apply across the whole of the banking sector," Carse said.
He said the HKMA could take firmer action if some institutions appeared to be falling behind by early 1998.
"We may have to be much more forceful in telling them that they've got to put this right. And that could take the form of formal action under the Banking Ordinance," he said.
The millennium bug is a potential glitch in software that runs computers. This threatens to crash systems on December 31, 1999, or cause them to spew out erroneous data.
The problem springs from short-cuts taken by computer programmers in the 1970s and 1980s.
To save memory, then in short supply, programmers shortened years to two digits -- "87" or "98", for example.
When the calendar clicks over to the year 2000, some computers will read the date as "00" and will either shut down or churn out misleading information.
